We're keeping it real, no fancy financial jargon, just the way we actually talk and deal with our paisa. So grab your chai, settle in, and let's get started!

unnormalised: First things first, the good old cash transaction. Remember those days when everything was ₹500 this and ₹2000 that? While UPI is all the rage these days, sometimes you just gotta deal with hard cash, especially at those small kirana shops or the local sabzi wala. Bargaining is still a national sport, and trust me, you can't bargain with Google Pay! I once managed to get a kilo of mangoes for ₹80 instead of ₹100 just by flashing a crumpled five-hundred rupee note. The power of persuasion, my friends!
normalised: First things first, the good old cash transaction. Remember those days when everything was rupee five hundred this and rupee two thousand that? While U-P-I is all the rage these days, sometimes you just gotta deal with hard cash, especially at those small kirana shops or the local sabzi wala. Bargaining is still a national sport, and trust me, you can't bargain with Google Pay! I once managed to get a kilo of mangoes for rupee eighty instead of rupee one hundred just by flashing a crumpled five-hundred rupee note. The power of persuasion, my friends!

unnormalised: Now, about banking. Let’s be honest, who enjoys going to the bank? The long queues, the forms… *shudders*. But sometimes you have to. Opening a new account? That’s Aadhaar card, PAN card, passport-sized photos, and a whole lot of patience. And don't even get me started on the minimum balance! If you're lucky, you might find a bank that doesn't demand you keep a whopping ₹5000 in your account at all times. Otherwise, those pesky charges will eat into your savings faster than you can say "RBI".

unnormalised: Speaking of the Reserve Bank of India (RBI), they’re constantly changing the rules, aren't they? One day they're introducing new ₹20 notes with funky designs, the next they're talking about digital currency. It’s hard to keep up! And don’t even get me started on the whole KYC (Know Your Customer) process. Every few years, you have to trot back to the bank with more documents to prove you're still you! It’s like they think we're all secretly trying to launder money!

unnormalised: Then there's the whole ATM situation. Finding a working ATM in some parts of the country is like searching for a unicorn. And when you finally find one, it’s either out of cash, the screen is broken, or some uncle is hogging it for 20 minutes trying to figure out how to withdraw ₹200. And don't forget the withdrawal limit – usually ₹10,000 or ₹20,000 per transaction. What if you need more?!

And don't forget the withdrawal limit – usually rupee ten thousand or rupee twenty thousand per transaction. What if you need more?!

unnormalised: But let's not forget the wonders of online banking. Transferring money using NEFT or RTGS? Super convenient! Especially when you need to send your cousin ₹2000 for that new saree she wants for Diwali. Although, the net banking passwords... a jumble of uppercase letters, lowercase letters, numbers, and special characters that I inevitably forget every single time. Luckily, most banks now have user-friendly apps, but even those can have their moments of frustration when the server is down.

unnormalised: And finally, a word about those pesky transaction fees. Some banks charge you for everything – from using another bank's ATM to even just checking your balance online! It's enough to make you want to stuff your mattress with cash instead. Seriously though, shop around for a bank with reasonable fees, or better yet, embrace UPI and say goodbye to those extra charges!
